issue.title: In lazy_split_view, comparing a default-constructed outer-iterator or inner-iterator with std::default_sentinel results in null pointer dereference

discussion.p: The internal iterator types outer-iterator and inner-iterator of lazy_split_view are default-constructible, but trying to compare a default-constructed instance of either of these classes to std::default_sentinel results in null pointer dereference (and, in all likelihood, a crash), as demonstrated in this demo link:
This is due to unchecked pointer access in the implementation of outer-iterator ( p8):

(parent_ is null for a default-constructed iterator x, making the access to base_ invalid)
And similarly for inner-iterator ( p7):

(For a default-constructed inner-iterator x, i_ is a default-constructed outer-iterator member variable and i_.parent_ is null, making the access to pattern_ invalid)
Note that neither operator== defines any preconditions.
It seems a reasonable expectation for users to expect comparing a default-constructed iterator to std::default_sentinel to be a well-defined operation that returns true. Alternatively, the corresponding operator== functions could have a Preconditions: element stating that the iterator cannot be default-constructed.

blockquote.pre: friend constexpr bool operator==(const outer-iterator& x, default_sentinel_t);
if (!x.parent_) return true; return x.current == ranges::end(x.parent_->base_) && !x.trailing_empty_;
friend constexpr bool operator==(const inner-iterator& x, default_sentinel_t);
